ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Mirroring and controlling an Android device's screen on a desktop computer for enhanced productivity, gaming, or development.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Display and control Android devices â€¢ USB or network connection â€¢ No root required â€¢ Cross-platform support (Windows, macOS, Linux) â€¢ Lightweight and high performance (30-60 fps)
ðŸ“– Summary: QtScrcpy is a lightweight, high-performance application for displaying and controlling Android devices on your computer via USB or network. It requires no root access and supports Windows, macOS, and Linux, offering low latency and fast startup times.

ðŸ’¡ weathr | Rust
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: To provide users with a visually engaging and informative real-time weather forecast directly within their terminal environment.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Real-time weather data from Open-Meteo â€¢ Animated ASCII art for weather conditions (rain, snow, thunderstorms, etc.) â€¢ Auto-location detection via IP â€¢ Customizable configuration for units, HUD visibility, and location display â€¢ CLI options for simulation and unit overrides
ðŸ“– Summary: Weathr is a command-line interface (CLI) application written in Rust that displays real-time weather information directly in the terminal. It features animated ASCII art for various weather conditions, auto-location detection, and customizable display options.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸŒŸ browserless | TypeScript
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Running automated browser tasks like web scraping, testing, and PDF generation in a scalable and manageable environment.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Dockerized headless browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Webkit) â€¢ Integration with Puppeteer and Playwright â€¢ Parallelism and queueing â€¢ Debug Viewer for real-time session inspection â€¢ Configurable timeouts
ðŸ“– Summary: Browserless is a Dockerized headless browser solution that allows users to deploy and manage Chrome, Firefox, or Webkit instances for automated tasks. It supports integration with Puppeteer and Playwright, offering features like parallelism, a debug viewer, and configurable timeouts, and can be run locally or used via their cloud service.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project â€¢ Homepage ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

âœ¨ SpotiFLAC | TypeScript
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Downloading Spotify music in high-fidelity FLAC format without needing a Spotify account.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Download Spotify tracks in FLAC â€¢ Source audio from Tidal, Qobuz, Amazon Music â€¢ No Spotify account required â€¢ Cross-platform support (Windows, macOS, Linux) â€¢ Free and open-source
ðŸ“– Summary: SpotiFLAC is a desktop application that allows users to download Spotify tracks in high-quality FLAC format. It sources audio from alternative streaming services like Tidal, Qobuz, and Amazon Music without requiring any user accounts or authentication with Spotify.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸŒŸ compressO | TypeScript
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Reducing video file sizes for easier storage, sharing, and faster uploads.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Cross-platform compatibility (Linux, Windows, macOS) â€¢ High video compression ratios â€¢ Powered by FFmpeg â€¢ Built with Tauri and Rust â€¢ Offline functionality
ðŸ“– Summary: CompressO is a cross-platform desktop application built with Tauri and Rust that allows users to significantly reduce video file sizes. It leverages FFmpeg for powerful video compression and offers a user-friendly interface for offline video conversion.
